content: The "Prescription Drug Benefit Equity Act of 1996" ensures equity in the provision of prescription drug coverage. The "Prescription Drug Benefit Equity Act of 1996" mandates that health plans offering mail-order prescription drug coverage must also provide non-mail-order prescription drug coverage with equitable benefits and cost-sharing. The "Prescription Drug Benefit Equity Act of 1996" requires health plans to provide equitable benefits and cost-sharing for non-mail-order prescription drug coverage compared to mail-order coverage. The "Prescription Drug Benefit Equity Act of 1996" requires equitable benefits and cost-sharing for non-mail-order prescription drug coverage compared to mail-order coverage. Requirements imposed on a health plan by a health maintenance organization or insurer are deemed to be imposed on the organization or insurer. The "Prescription Drug Benefit Equity Act of 1996" requires equitable benefits and cost-sharing for non-mail-order prescription drug coverage compared to mail-order coverage. Requirements imposed on a health plan by a health maintenance organization or insurer are deemed to be imposed on the organization or insurer. Enforcement is addressed in Section 3. Each State must ensure that health plans issued by HMOs meet the requirements outlined in Section 2. If a State fails to enforce these requirements, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement an enforcement plan. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will enforce requirements for health maintenance organizations and insurers in states that fail to do so. Civil enforcement measures will be taken under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Secretary of Labor will enforce requirements for employee health benefit plans. The Secretary of Labor will enforce requirements for benefit plans in the same manner as specified in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Civil penalties will apply to any required information. For health plans under specific categories, the requirements of section 2 will be treated as state plan requirements or conditions for contracting with the plan. The Secretaries of Labor and Health and Human Services, along with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, may create regulations to implement the Act. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION; PREEMPTION. In General, this Act allows health plans to restrict drugs and impose limitations on benefits and cost-sharing as long as they are consistent with the Act. State laws can establish standards for prescription drug coverage that are not in direct conflict with this Act and provide greater benefits. The Act allows health plans to restrict drugs and impose limitations on benefits and cost-sharing as long as they are consistent with the Act. State laws can establish standards for prescription drug coverage that do not conflict with the Act and provide greater protection or benefit to participants. Nothing in the Act affects the provisions of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "health plan" in this Act refers to employee welfare benefit plans providing medical care to employees or their dependents through insurance or other means, including group health plans. The term "mail-order prescription drug coverage" refers to benefits for prescription drugs delivered through mail or similar means. It includes coverage under various health plans and government programs. Non-mail-order prescription drug coverage provides benefits for prescription drugs through local pharmacies within a specified distance of the beneficiary's residence. Employee health benefit plan includes any plan that provides health benefits for participants and beneficiaries, whether directly or through a health maintenance organization or insurer. It also encompasses health benefit plans under the Peace Corps Act. (6) Health maintenance organization or HMO refers to a federally qualified organization, a state-recognized entity, or a similar organization regulated for solvency under state law. (7) Insurer is defined as an insurance company, service, or organization. An insurer is an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to do business in a State and subject to State insurance regulations. State refers to various regions including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and others. The Act applies to health plans described in section 5(1)(A) for plan years starting more than 6 months after enactment, and to other health plans for contract years starting more than 6 months after enactment.
